historicEventInformations.remarks: [Jochen Luckhardt, in Exhib. Cat. Münster 1985, No. 61]

pageContext.description:
The reformer is shown as a bust-length portrait against a light green background with a cast shadow to the left. His face has a light brown complexion, while his gaze is directed obliquely upwards. His hair is grey with unkempt curls that cover his forehead. The gown appears today as a monotone black, originally the angled collar continued down to the bottom. The white shirt visible at the neckline is bound with a black cord, beneath which there is a red braid.  
[Cat. Münster 1990, No. 232]

tests.text:
DESCRIPTION

Tools/Material: 
- fluid, dark medium, brush; possibly in two stages 

Type/Ductus: 
- relatively economic, freehand underdrawing 
- thin to somewhat broader lines; occasionally searching 

Function: 
- relatively binding for the final painted version; the lines delineate the main contours, define forms therein and describe facial features; no representation of volume with hatching strokes

Deviations:
- minor corrections were made to forms during the painting process; small changes (e. g. in the faces and the landscape at the bottom edge) 

INTERPRETATION

Attribution: 
- Lucas Cranach the Elder or workshop (?)

Comments:
- probably transferred freehand from a pre-existing design 
[Sandner, Smith-Contini, Heydenreich, cda 2017]
